{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Sheila Scott |image = SheilaScott Mythre 1971.jpg |caption = Before her 1971 record-breaking trip |birth_name = Sheila Christine Hopkins |birth_date = {{Birth date|1922|04|27|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Worcester]], [[Worcestershire]], [[England]], UK |death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|10|20|1922|04|27|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Royal Marsden Hospital]], [[London]], England, UK |occupation = Aviator |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]]}}
'''Sheila Scott''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (27 April 1922 – 20 October 1988), was an English [[aviator]] who broke over 100 aviation records through her long distance flight endeavours, which included a {{convert|34000|mi|km|adj=on}} "world and a half" flight in 1971. On this flight, she became the first person to fly over the [[North Pole]] in a small aircraft.
==Early years== Born '''Sheila Christine Hopkins''' in [[Worcester]], [[Worcestershire]], England,<ref>[[General Register Office]] index of births registered in April, May, June 1922. Name: Hopkins, Sheila C. Mother's Maiden name: Kenward. District: Worcester. Volume: 6C. Page: 239.</ref> she had a turbulent childhood and did not do well at [[the Alice Ottley School]], nearly being expelled several times. During World War II, she joined the services as a nurse in a naval hospital.<ref name="soloflights"/><ref name="spectator"/>
==Flying== In 1943, she started a career as an actress as '''Sheila Scott''', a name she maintained long after she stopped acting. She had a short marriage from 1945 to 1950 to Rupert Bellamy.<ref name="monash">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctie.monash.edu.au/hargrave/scott_sheila.html|title=Sheila Scott (1927–1988), Pioneer Aviatrix|website=Aviation Pioneers : An Anthology|publisher=CTIE|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
In 1958 she learned to fly going solo at [[Thruxton Aerodrome]] after nine months of training. Her first aircraft was a [[Thruxton Jackaroo]] (converted Tiger Moth) ''G-APAM'' which she owned from 1959 to 1964.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://publicapps.caa.co.uk/docs/HistoricalMaterial/G-APAM-1.pdf|title=UK Register of Civil Aircraft – register entry – G-APAM-1|publisher=Civil Aviation Authority|format=PDF}}</ref> In April 1966 she bought her [[Piper PA-24 Comanche|Piper Comanche]] 260B ''G-ATOY'' named ''Myth Too'' in which she set ninety world records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://publicapps.caa.co.uk/docs/HistoricalMaterial/G-ATOY.pdf|title=UK Register of Civil Aircraft – register entry – G-ATOY|publisher=Civil Aviation Authority|format=PDF}}</ref> Her first solo round the world flight commenced at London Heathrow on 18 May 1966 and returned on 20 June 1966, having covered approximately 31,000 miles (49,890 kilometres) on 189 flying hours in 34 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.womeninaerospacehistory.com/tag/piper-pa-24-260b-comanche/|first=Bryan R.|last=Swopes|title=Piper PA-24-260B Comanche|website=Women in Aerospace History|date=18 May 2015|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> In 1969–70 she flew solo around the world in the same aircraft a second time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soloflights.org/list2_e.html|title=List of solo flights around the world|first=Claude|last=Meunier|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> This aircraft was severely damaged in 1979 (after she sold it in 1971) and the remains are on display in the collection of the [[National Museum of Flight]], East Fortune, East Lothian, Scotland. She later used a borrowed Piper Comanche 400 ''N8515P'' to set more records.
On 20 November 1966, she appeared as a contestant on the American panel show ''[[What's My Line]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0747023/?ref_=ttep_ep41|title=What's My Line IMDb episode listing|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref>
In 1971 she bought a twin-engined [[Piper Aztec]] 250 ''G-AYTO'' named ''Mythre'' <ref>http://publicapps.caa.co.uk/docs/HistoricalMaterial/G-AYTO.pdf</ref> in which she completed her third solo round the world flight in the same year.<ref name="soloflights"/> This aircraft was destroyed in a flood at the Piper factory in [[Lock Haven, Pennsylvania|Lock Haven]] in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.womeninaerospacehistory.com/11-june-4-august-1971-sheila-scott/|first=Bryan R.|last=Swopes|title=11 June–4 August 1971: Sheila Scott, OBE|website=Women in Aerospace History|date=11 June 2015|accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref>
==Affiliations== She was the founder, and the first governor, of the British branch of the [[Ninety-Nines]], an association for licensed women pilots, which had been created by [[Amelia Earhart]]. She was a member of the International Association of Licensed Women Pilots, and of the [[Whirly-Girls]], an association of women helicopter pilots.<ref name="soloflights">{{cite web|url=http://www.soloflights.org/scott_data_e.html|title=Sheila Scott 1. Data File|website=soloflights.org|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="spectator">{{cite news|url=http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/29th-october-1988/24/the-high-deeds-of-sheila-scott|first=Judy|last=Lomax|title=The High Deeds of Sheila Scott|publisher=The Spectator|date=29 October 1988|page=24|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
==Honours and awards== She was appointed an [[Order of the British Empire|Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in 1968.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=44484|date=1 January 1968|page=14}}</ref> One of the teaching buildings at the [[University of Worcester]] is named after her.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.worcester.ac.uk/documents/Sheila_Scott_Brochure.pdf |title=University of Worcester Clinical Skills & Simulation Centre Sheila Scott Building |publisher=University of Worcester |accessdate=26 April 2018}}</ref>
She received the Brabazon of Tara Award in 1965, 1967, 1968.<ref name="soloflights"/><ref name="spectator"/> She received the [[Britannia Trophy]] of the Royal Aero Club of Britain in 1968.<ref name="soloflights"/><ref name="spectator"/> She received the Royal Aero Club's Gold Medal (1972).<ref name="EB">{{Britannica|529621}}</ref>
==Death== Before her death, Scott lived in a bedsit in [[Pimlico]] in poverty. She was diagnosed with cancer and died at age 66 at the [[Royal Marsden Hospital]], London, in 1988.<ref name="soloflights"/><ref name="spectator"/>
